title: Card Factory reports profit surge but warns on living wage
text:

Tue, Sep 22, 2015, 10:10 BST - UK Markets close in 6 hrs 20 mins Card Factory reports profit surge but warns on living wage By Julia Bradshaw | Telegraph – 21 minutes ago 356.70 -2.1000 
Greeting cards retailer rewards shareholders with £51m payout but says Government's new wage policy will push up costs next year 
Card Factory has rewarded shareholders with a generous special dividend after reporting a 72pc rise in underlying pre-tax profit to £25.7m in the first-half, but warned that the government's new minimum wage could hit margins next year. 
The £51.1m return of cash reflects a 15p per share payout and comes on top of an interim dividend of 2.5p. 
Chief executive Richard Hayes said the payment followed a strong period of trading as the greeting cards maker pressed ahead with its strategy of rolling out new stores, slashing costs, improving its product range and boosting like-for-like sales. 
That plan has so far proved successful: like-for-likes - which strip out new stores - rose 3pc in the six months to the end of July, while Card Factory (LSE: CARD.L - news ) opened a net 36 stores, bringing the total to 800 across the UK. 
Management expects a total of 50 new openings by the end of the year and believes the group will continue to win market share. 
However, Mr Hayes said the Government's new living wage, introduced in July's summer Budget, would push up costs next year. He added that the company's margins could be vulnerable to foreign exchange movements, as Card Factory sources many of its products in Asia. 
Still, Mr Hayes said the retailer's vertically integrated business model put it in a strong position to withstand these forthcoming cost pressures. He added that the group was tackling these "margin headwinds" by looking at ways to take costs out of the business. 
Card Factory, which sells greeting cards for as little as 29p, is, quite literally, a card factory, designing and printing most of the products in-house. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) therefore enjoys higher than average profit margins, which remained flat year-on-year at 20.1pc. 
That was despite making improvements to the quality of many of its greeting cards while introducing fresh product ranges. Meanwhile, a new website underpinned by more effective technology has resulted in a "step change" in revenues, according to management. 
Elsewhere in the group Getting Personal, Card Factory's online personalised gift and card store, enjoyed a 25pc jump in sales to £6.9m and an 8pc increase in profits as margins widened. However, management has warned that the business faces tougher comparatives in the second-half. 
Private equity group Charterhouse, which bought the business for £350m in 2010, listed the greeting cards retailer on the stock market last year, valuing it at £766m. 
In June, Card Factory's senior management made almost £50m from selling shares in the retailer. 
Mr Hayes collected £9.6m, while Darren Bryant, the finance director, received £4.7m. The rest was shared between nine other senior managers, sending the share price down 8pc on the day it was announced. 
To allow for the special dividend payment, the company has refinanced its existing £200m debt facility, which also gives it an extra £100m wiggle room.
